awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Christopher Switzer at the University of California-Riverside, to develop metal mediated base pairs that are capable of participating in information transfer reactions alongside their natural counterparts. To accomplish this objective, metal mediated base pair motifs will be developed with optimal shape and size for acceptance by natural enzymes. The work under the award will build on preliminary studies by the PI's laboratory to create a next generation metal mediated base pair capable of such function. This next generation base pair uses a tridentate purine-like component and a monodentate pyrimidine-like component to coordinate a divalent metal ion, such as Cu2+. The function of metal mediated base pairs with natural polymerase enzymes will be explored and optimized by employing a range of different monodentate nucleotides chosen on the basis of synthetic expediency and known optimal design features.

Watson-Crick base pairs encode genetic information in all organisms. While natural base pairs rely on hydrogen bonds for recognition, other weak or reversible interactions hold promise for the creation of non-standard base pairs. Metal-mediated bonds have been shown recently to replace hydrogen bonds between non-standard bases in the DNA helix. The next steps in the progression to achieve functional metal-mediated base pairs are therefore now within reach. The program of study will provide a solid training ground for graduate students in chemical biology. Additionally, research opportunities for undergraduate students will be offered during the proposal period, including a summer undergraduate research position for underrepresented minorities or women.

por.por_cntn:
DNA and RNA encode genetic information with a four-letter alphabet of purine and pyrimidine nucleobases: A, G, C or T/U. These heterocycles are appended to the anomeric carbon of a ribose sugar, which in turn is attached to phosphate via an ester linkage to form nucleotides. DNA and RNA strands formally derive by linking nucleotides with phosphodiester bonds. Replication of DNA strands, the transcription of DNA into RNA and the translation of mRNA into proteins are all processes that rely on information transfer mediated by nucleobases in DNA (AGCT) and/or RNA (AGCU).

Nature employs two Watson-Crick base pairs to encode information: A=T/U and G=C. The bases form hydrogen bonded base pairs (HBBPs) through complementary arrays of two or three hydrogen-bond donor and acceptor atoms. When generalized, the natural Watson-Crick hydrogen bond donor/acceptor arrays represent two from the set of eight possible pairs. Many of the six non-standard Watson-Crick hydrogen-bonding arrays have been the subject of study over the past 30 years. While several of the these additional pairing schemes have shown viability in one or more of the information transfer processes noted above, they are still a work in progress.

Non-hydrogen bonded Watson-Crick base-pairs (NHBBPs) represent an alternative means of enhancing the information content of nucleic acids. In principle, any interactions between two molecules that are reversible could substitute for hydrogen bonding interactions found in Watson-Crick base pairs. Approaches to NHBBPs include the replacement of hydrogen bonds with either hydrophobic interactions or metal-mediated coordination bonds. The studies proposed here concern the latter approach to NHBBPs.

The Switzer laboratory has developed a suite of metal-mediated base pairs (MMBPs) that utilize purine or pyrimidine core structures appended with donor groups. MMBPs developed by the Switzer laboratory include: PurP•Ni2+•PurP, PyrP•Ni2+•PyrP, PyrBP•Ag+•4-P, PurBP•Ag+•4-P, and PurDP•Ag+•3-P (Pur = purine, Pyr = pyrimidine, P = pyridyl, DP = dipyridyl, BP = bipyridyl). These base pairs have been characterized within synthetic DNA double helices, mainly through the use of UV monitored thermal denaturation.

This proposal sought to develop MMBPs with transcendent properties -- MMBPs whose self- recognition is orthogonal to HBBPs, but still capable of seamless participation in information transfer reactions alongside HBBP counterparts. To accomplish this objective, MMBP motifs were developed with smaller footprints than previous motifs, while still retaining a natural nucleobase core. Recognition and information transfer using these new MMBP motifs was explored over the grant period.

The specific MMBP motifs synthesized and tested contained PurDC•Cu2+•azole, where PurDC (2,6-dicarboxypurine) is related to the larger natural purine bases G and C and the azole (five membered ring nitrogen heterocycles) is related to the smaller natural pyrimidine bases C and T. PurDC•Cu2+•azole was chosen as a test bed to improve on our preliminary results with MMBP PurDC•Cu2+•3-P which, while able to be recognized and synthesized by polymerases, was unable to be universally extended. Five different azole containing nucleotide monomers were synthesized for DNA double helix thermal and polymerase enzyme studies in the context of a PurDC•Cu2+•azole MMBP. Of the five PurDC•Cu2+•azole MMBP's studied during the grant period, two stood out as superior in terms of both their pairing strength in a DNA helix and enzyme mediated synthesis. Additionally, of the many commercial DNA polymerases screened, one in particular was found to synthesize and extend the two best PurDC•Cu2+•azole MMBP's. Future work will focus on improving the efficiency of polymerase copying and extension of these two MMBP's with polymerase mutants.

The creation of a metal ion mediated base pair with functional properties that are fully consistent with natural informational polymers, including enzymatic processing, will contribute to longer-term goals in the areas of DNAzymes/aptamers, materials, unnatural protein synthesis, and synthetic biology.

The expansion of the genetic code using metal-mediated base pairs as pursued under this grant award will impact other scientific disciplines, especially medicine and biology. In particular, expanded metal mediated base pairs will impact medical diagnostics by providing enhancements to PCR and hybridization assays, enable access to improved nucleic acid antibody analogs (e.g. modified aptamters and ribozymes), allow the synthesis of proteins with non-standard amino acids in vitro, and contribute to the development of synthetic biology.
